Eko, you can try the approach in that paper if you want but if you want t=
o use NEAT for classification and you are just learning about NEAT for the =
first time it's probably easiest to just use regular NEAT by itself.

ken

> Judul: Re : Bls=

>

> Hi,
> Download one of the NEAT imple=
mentation (don't ask me which one is the best, 
> it's your choice). Run ba=
sic examples, like learning the XOR function, a often 
> included example o=
f supervised learning. Read the paper that introduce NEAT, not 
> all, but =
at least the section about how it's done, a one hour effort. If you 
> data=
 are vector of fixed size, it's very straighfoward to move from the XOR 
> =
example to your problem.
> 
> But anyway, if the real problem is to actuall=
y build a classifier and not 
> tinkering with NEAT, better first have a go=
od reason to use NEAT and not 
> something more simple (Occam razor princip=
le). A perceptron with backprop, you 
> got plenty of implementations for i=
t in the most esotheric languages, and it's 
> easy to do your own if you w=
ish to. Same goes for SVM, if you don't use fancy 
> kernels. And both are =
likely to be faster for many supervised learning tasks. I 
> might be corre=
cted by the others, but I think the original purpose of NEAT was 
> to do *=
UNSUPERVISED* learning. Don't expect a less informed algorithm to be 
> bet=
ter than a better informed one :p
> 
> Alex
>

> Judul: Re : [neat] ask about NEAT

> 
> Hi,
> 
> NEAT optimiz=
e neural network. NEAT will generate many neural network, and you 
> give a=
 *fitness* to each neural network. Higher fitness means more interesting 
>=
 neural network.
> 
> Thus, with NEAT, you can produce neural networks that=
 can themselves can be used 
> for doing classification. Your fitness for a=
 given neural network should be its 
> classification performance. To avoid=
 over-learning (a classifier which does not 
> generalize), be careful to n=
ot use the same sample set to compute classification 
> performance.
> 
> A=
lso, be sure that more classic machine learning methods are not suitable, l=
ike 
> SVM or back-prop, they are likely to be faster if they work good eno=
ugh on your 
> problem. Those methods are less general than NEAT but can ex=
ploit some 
> properties specific to supervised learning for speed gain.
> =

> Alex
